comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Great shot.  Looking at the implement the man on the left was operating I suspect that it helped them to form up the cask?  Any experts out there to tell us how it was done?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Would indeed welcome input from any coopers out there! It looks as if the foot pedal thingy (technical term) helped to increase pressure on the hoops??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: Looks more like a fire, the foot pedal would pump air into it to increase the heat. The hoops are heated before they are put around the cask.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I think you're right Michiel!  I was looking at the shape but when you view it at original size you can see it a lot better and it seems to be a portable furnace - for heating the rivets perhaps?  I like the specialised anvil the other cooper is working on, specially adapted for his needs and no need for bending the back unnecessarily!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ah, that makes sense - a sort of brazier type affair...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 50969511@N02
comment._content: That seems so grimy and sooty. I can imagine the black on their handkerchiefs when they blew their noses. The odd things is that they look so clean.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/stevetaylors] It's really the walls and ceiling that are filthy. Their own work space seems relatively clean. Wonder if it was years of open fire coopering that led to such smuts and soot, or if some other activity was carried on there...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Company still in business and owned still by the De Bromhead (also horse trainers) family. They operate a fine pub and still sell a fine whiskey of their own Downe's No.9.

comment.author: 46244913@N06
comment._content: hi.man on left heating the rivets is Jimmy Maher , The Bullring Slieverue.Jimmy Hennessy from Barracks street is to his right.Jimmy maher worked here till his retirement doing all sorts of jobs ,washing and botteling , lableing bottles, corking,delevering and blending the famous no 9.Jimmy Hennessy later worked in Batterburrys pub Barracks street, [the one that the plane landed on ].Jim Mahers daughter latter married Jim Hennessy's som Maurice.. my father ... my name is Conn.comfirmed today by my father , mother, and her brother michael.. ps michael is now 74 years old.these men are in other old photos too

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/46244913@N06] Thank you so much, Conn! This is absolutely amazing information to have, and it's really lovely to have the link with our Barrack Street photo (the one that the plane landed on). Will you please thank all of your family? And don't hesitate to comment on any of our other Waterford photos if you recognise faces or places...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 46244913@N06
comment._content: your very welcome [NLI] thank you. Some brilliant photos on here i give hours looking.
